title: Verdict in case over Bangladesh child who died after falling into abandoned deep tube-well on Feb 26
text:
Verdict in case over Bangladesh child's death after falling into abandoned deep tube-well on Feb 26 Court Correspondent bdnews24.com   16:36:36.0   16:59:48.0 BdST Rescuers had called of their search after 23 hours, but locals managed to pull out Jihad soon afterwards but he was dead by then. File photo The trial over the death of 4-year-old Jihad, who fell into an unsealed pipe of an abandoned deep tube-well in Dhaka, has concluded. 
On Wednesday, a special judge's court kept its verdict pending for Feb 26 after hearing the closing arguments. 
On Dec 26, 2014, Jihad fell into a deep tube-well for the Bangladesh Railway at Dhaka’s Shahjahanpur. 
He fell through the pipe’s 14-inch opening, which was kept unsealed even after it was abandoned. 
Rescuers had called off their search after 23 hours, but the locals refused to give up. They finally pulled out Jihad soon afterwards but the child was dead by then. 
Doctors at the Dhaka Medical College and Hospital said then he had died several hours before being taken to the hospital. The 4-year-old boy fell into the abandoned deep tube-well while playing with his friends. Photo taken from family album. The death shook the nation and calls to bring those responsible to justice for keeping the pipe unsealed resonated across the country.
Jihad's father filed a case of death due to negligence with the Shahjanpur police. 
In April 2015, police filed the chargesheet in court, where it pressed charges on Railway Senior Sub-Assistant Engineer Jahangir Alam, who was in charge of the project and Abdus Salam, the contractor who set up the well. Jiahd fell trough the 14-inch opening of this unsealed pipe. File photo After the plaintiff objected, the court ordered a fresh probe and a second chargesheet, adding four more railway officials, was filed on Mar 31 last year.
They are railway's Kamalapur zone assistant engineers Md Nasir Uddin and Dipak Kumar Bhoumik, Assistant Engineer-2 Md Saiful Islam and Electric Engineer Abu Ahmed Shaki. 
On Oct 4, 2016, the trial began after the court indicted the six. 
They have been charged under Bangladesh Penal Code's Section 304A, which says "Whoever causes the death of any person by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to five years, or with fine, or with both."
